conclusion: ρ – density of water, σ – surface-tension coefficient, g – acceleration of gravity, d – inside diameter of the nozzle (d ≪ r so the meniscus in the neck is almost cylindrical), r – radius of the nearly spherical pendent drop
Weight of the drop W = (4⁄3)π r³ ρ g.
The circular rim that joins the drop to the tube has circumference l = πd.
Because the liquid–air interface exists on both the inside and the outside of the tube, two rims are present, so the upward force supplied by surface tension is Fσ = 2 σ l = 2σ π d.
A drop leaves when its weight is just equal to the maximum upward force that surface tension can supply: (4⁄3)π r³ ρ g = 2σ π d.
Maximum radius r_max = [ (3 σ d)/(2 ρ g) ]^{1/3}.

While the drop is still connected to the water column it is at the same potential φ as the nozzle; therefore no electric field acts across the neck and the electrostatic contribution to the vertical force is negligible.
The electrostatic energy of the whole conductor is almost unchanged by the small vertical motion of the yet‐unseparated drop.
Consequently the detachment criterion and the radius found above are not altered by the applied potential.
Final result r_max = [ (3 σ d)/(2 ρ g) ]^{1/3}.
